htmlEmbed:
DoNotPay, the 'Robot Lawyer,' Is Being SuedGizmodo3/13/2023

A class action lawsuit claims Joshua Browder's start-up misled consumers by peddling "substandard legal documents" and providing "unauthorized legal services."

donotpay, civilprocedure, law, complaint, joshuabrowder, jonathanfaridian, edelson, kathryntewson, plaintiff, cbsnews, government, causeofaction, amazon, jayedelson, magnitskyact, englishpeople, law2ccrime, jon, lawsuit, corruptioninrussia, DoNotPay, Civil procedure, Law, Complaint, Joshua Browder, Jonathan Faridian, Edelson, Kathryn Tewson, Plaintiff, CBS News, Government, Cause of action, Amazon, Jay Edelson, Magnitsky Act, English people, Crime, Jon, Lawsuit, Corruption in Russia, GizmodoRead

dNvqfo"><div class="sc-235a11-0 gAWpVd"><a class="sc-1out364-0 dPMosf sc-fek4t4-0 gSkeaw js_link" data-ga="[["Permalink meta","Channel click","/tech/news"]]" href="/tech/news"><div class="sc-fek4t4-1 hPMVdY">News</div></a></div><header class="sc-1efpnfq-1 blDizU"><h1 class="sc-1efpnfq-0 dQNvfv">DoNotPay, the 'Robot Lawyer,' Is Being Sued</h1></header><h2 class="sc-1xcxnn7-0 fkxmmQ js_regular-subhead">A class action lawsuit claims Joshua Browder's start-up misled consumers by peddling "substandard legal documents" and providing "unauthorized legal services."</h2></div></div><div class="sc-157agsr-0 kQaSNa"><main class="sc-11qwj9y-1 jFItit"><div class="sc-11qwj9y-0 iKQGg"><script type="application/ld+json">{"@type":"NewsArticle","@context":"http://schema.org","url":"https://gizmodo.com/donotpay-robot-lawyer-speeding-ticket-ai-1850218589","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Lauren Leffer"}],"headline":"DoNotPay, the 'Robot Lawyer,' Is Being Sued","description":"A class action lawsuit claims Joshua Browder's start-up misled consumers by peddling \"substandard legal documents\" and providing \"unauthorized legal services.\"","dateline":"03/13/2023 at 12:05","datePublished":"2023-03-13T12:05:00-04:00","dateModified":"2023-03-13T12:49:04-04:00","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","url":"https://gizmodo.com/donotpay-robot-lawyer-speeding-ticket-ai-1850218589"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","height":675,"width":1200,"url":"https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/c_fill,f_auto,fl_progressive,g_center,h_675,pg_1,q_80,w_1200/ec120c08494eb6bc726c995f66e06d2e.png","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","height":180,"width":320,"url":"https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/c_fill,f_auto,fl_progressive,g_center,h_180,pg_1,q_80,w_320/ec120c08494eb6bc726c995f66e06d2e.png"}},"articleBody":"The startup behind the worlds first robot lawyer, DoNotPay, is gearing up for one of its first big court battles. And this time it probably cant just back out of the case, as DoNotPay is the defendant. The company is facing a class action lawsuit over allegations that it misled customers and misrepresented its product. \n\n\nIn the complaint (embedded below) filed March 3 in a San Francisco court and published Thursday, the plaintiffs legal team claims that DoNotPays description of itself as the worlds first robot lawyer is incorrect and unlawful. Further it alleges that the companys self-billing and lofty promises led its customers to believe they were receiving high quality legal advice and documents when they werent. \n\nUnfortunately for its customers, DoNotPay is not actually a robot, a lawyer, nor a law firm. DoNotPay does not have a law degree, is not barred in any jurisdiction, and is not supervised by any lawyer, the suit reads. DoNotPay is merely a website with a repository ofunfortunately, substandardlegal documents that at best fills in a legal adlib based on information input by customers, it adds. The legal filing goes on to accuse the company of violating California code by practicing law without a license.\n\n Among other things, the suit cites a DoNotPay customer review in which someone reportedly tried to use the service to dispute two parking tickets and ended up paying more money because the company didnt respond to a summons. After trying to cancel their account, the customer was still charged a subscription fee by DoNotPay, per the lawsuit. \n\nThough Gizmodo couldnt immediately locate this particular review, the internet is chock-full of poor reviews of the startup that repeatedly reference challenges canceling subscriptionswhich is deeply ironic considering one of the primary use cases the company has claimed for itself is in helping consumers navigate corporate bureaucracy to cancel subscriptions and get their money back. \n\nThe lawsuit further goes into the specific case of primary plaintiff, Jonathan Faridian. It claims that Faridian used DoNotPays services up until January 2023 and found them severely lacking. The complaint alleges that, in at least one instance, DoNotPay failed to deliver demand letters to their intended recipients. It also states that, on several occasions, documents Faridian purchased from DoNotPay were so poorly or inaccurately drafted that he could not even use them.\n\nDoNotPay is a company thats made a name for itself on the internet for its claims of helping customers to get out of parking tickets, reclaim funds from cable companies, and manage other low-grade legal and consumer snafusmostly by generating template based documents. \n\nYet earlier this year, the company announced it was aiming higher than it had before with the help of OpenAIs ChatGPT. DoNotPay claimed it was taking a pilot version of an AI-powered robot lawyer into the court room, to fight a speeding ticket charge before a judge. The companys founder and CEO, Joshua Browder, also offered to pay $1 million to any lawyer willing to let its artificial intelligence argue a case before the U.S. Supreme Court. Neither the traffic court, nor the Supreme Court dreams panned out for DoNotPay, though. A bevvy of legal threats shut down Browders lofty goal of disrupting the legal industry. \n\nSince then, the company and Browder have faced a wave of criticism, most prominently from those involved in the legal field, like paralegal Kathryn Tewsons viral takedown. Tewson has also begun legal proceedings against Browder and DoNotPay, alleging fraud in a lawsuit filed to New York States Supreme Court in February.\n\nBack in JanuaryBrowder subsequently announced DoNotPay would step back from its courtroom and lawyer-replacement goals (calling them distractions), and pivot its focus fully to consumer rights. Yet the company continues to bill itself the worlds first robot lawyer, on its website. \n\nIn response to the class action suit CEO Browder, posted a lengthy Twitter thread criticizing the basis of the complaint and the law firm arguing the case against him. His thread mostly focuses in on Jay Edelson, the senior attorney on the case who is well-known for aggressively going after major tech companies like Google, Apple, and Amazonand winning large settlements. \n\nJay Edelson inspired me to start DoNotPay because he symbolizes everything wrong with the law, Browder tweetedciting a 2015 class action Facebook settlement in which Edelsons firm earned $97.5 million while most people eligible for compensation who filled out the claim form got a few hundred bucks. \n\nGranted, that payout to the law firm is a pretty standard 15% fee on a hefty $650 million settlement fund, per the U.S. Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals that rejected Facebooks objections to the attorney fees in 2022.\n\nBrowders tweets also critique Faridian as a plaintiff. According to Faridians LinkedIn profile, he is an entrepreneur who studied law at the American Heritage University School of Law. He also claims to be currently studying law at Purdue Universitys online Concord Law School.\n\nAnd it does seem a little odd that someone with a formal legal education would be using an online service to draft demand letters. Gizmodo reached out to Faridians legal team for more information, yet did not immediately receive a response. However, to CBS News, attorney Edelson said, Jon is not a lawyer and has never held himself out as such. As his LinkedIn profile explained, he took classes in pursuit of a JD at American Heritage. We agree that the profile could have been clearer and Jon has updated it. \n\nIn addition to the tweet thread, Browder also shared the following statement with Gizmodo via text message:\n\nDoNotPay respectfully denies the false allegations. The named plaintiff has submitted dozens of successful cases to DoNotPay and the cases highlighted in this lawsuit are meritless. Furthermore, the case is being filed by a lawyer who has personally been paid hundreds of millions from class actions, so its unsurprising that he would accuse an AI of unauthorized practice of law. We will defend ourselves vigorously.\n\nWhich brings us to the question of who is we and how, exactly, will DoNotPay opt to defend itself? Will the company lean on the established mores of the legal institution and hire a law firm, or will it be self-representing with a robot? \n\nOut of curiosity, I ran the companys statement through a few different AI-generated content detectors, to get a sense of Browders strategy thus far. Most of them suggested the text was highly likely to have been written by a human (although in most cases I had to paste the statement more than once to meet the minimum word count). OpenAIs own text classifier listed the statement (repeated 3x to meet the min) as possibly AI-generated. Though, no AI-detector is perfectly reliable. \n\nGizmodo also asked Browder directly if DoNotPay would be hiring a lawyer for its defense, or self-defending in court using the companys own tools. In response, Browder declined to respond and said, I apologize given the pending nature of the litigation I cant comment further. However, in his Thursday tweet thread, the CEO wrote, We may even use our robot lawyer in the case.\n\nUpdate 3/13/2023, 12:48 P.M. ET: This post has been updated with additional information about another, earlier lawsuit filed against DoNotPay. legal team claims that DoNotPays description of itself as the worlds first robot lawyer is incorrect and unlawful. Further it alleges that the companys self-billing and lofty promises led its customers to believe they were receiving high quality legal advice and documents when they werent. </p><div class="sc-1xxadal-0 jCxDxJ js_related-stories-inset"></div><div class="sc-17kx9cd-5 kDVAgq js_ad-mobile-dynamic js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic"><div class="sc-17kx9cd-1 sc-17kx9cd-2 bGgkuB cLmdPT"></div><div class="sc-17kx9cd-4 bNalOf ad-unit ad-mobile"><div class="sc-17kx9cd-0 fjNuCW">Advertisement</div><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-MOBILE_IN_POST ad-mobile placement-default" data-dfp-site-code="gm.gizmodo" data-ad-unit="MOBILE_IN_POST" data-targeting="{"pos":"mobile_inpost","postId":"1850218589","blogName":"gizmodo","tags":"donotpay,civilprocedure,law,complaint,joshuabrowder,jonathanfaridian,edelson,kathryntewson,plaintiff,cbsnews,government,causeofaction,amazon,jayedelson,magnitskyact,englishpeople,law2ccrime,jon,lawsuit,corruptioninrussia","channel":"tech","section":"news"}"></div><div class="bt-wrapper"><span data-uid="5d260804c9-384" class="bt-uid-tg" style="display:none !important;text-align:center" data-css-selector="ad-container.ad-mobile"></span></div></div><div class="sc-17kx9cd-1 sc-17kx9cd-3 bGgkuB kTRrxu"></div></div><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv">Unfortunately for its customers, DoNotPay is not actually a robot, a lawyer, nor a law firm. DoNotPay does not have a law degree, is not barred in any jurisdiction, and is not supervised by any lawyer, the suit reads. DoNotPay is merely a website with a repository ofunfortunately, substandardlegal documents that at best fills in a legal adlib based on information input by customers, it adds. The legal filing goes on to accuse the company of violating California code by practicing law without a license.</p><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv"> Among other things, the suit cites a DoNotPay customer review in which someone reportedly tried to use the service to dispute two parking tickets and ended up paying more money because the company didnt respond to a summons. After trying to cancel their account, the customer was still charged a subscription fee by DoNotPay, per the lawsuit. </p><div class="sc-bxm4mm-7 jKZusJ"><div class="sc-1atgi65-0 sc-19jt9hn-12 cNXJZN href="https://cookcountyrecord.com/stories/622170728-appeals-court-oks-97-5m-for-lawyers-who-got-650m-from-facebook-in-photo-tags-class-action" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">rejected Facebooks objections to the attorney fees</a></span> in 2022.</p><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv">Browders tweets also critique Faridian as a plaintiff. According to <span><a class="sc-1out364-0 dPMosf sc-145m8ut-0 jCErAQ js_link" data-ga="[["Embedded Url","External link","https://www.linkedin.com/in/jonathan-faridian-a7b142a5/",{"metric25":1}]]" href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/jonathan-faridian-a7b142a5/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Faridians LinkedIn profile</a></span>, he is an entrepreneur who studied law at the American Heritage University School of Law. He also claims to be currently studying law at Purdue Universitys online Concord Law School.</p><div class="sc-17kx9cd-5 kDVAgq js_ad-mobile-dynamic js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic"><div class="sc-17kx9cd-1 sc-17kx9cd-2 bGgkuB cLmdPT"></div><div class="sc-17kx9cd-4 bNalOf ad-unit ad-mobile"><div class="sc-17kx9cd-0 fjNuCW">Advertisement</div><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-MOBILE_IN_POST ad-mobile placement-default" data-dfp-site-code="gm.gizmodo" data-ad-unit="MOBILE_IN_POST" data-targeting="{"pos":"mobile_inpost","postId":"1850218589","blogName":"gizmodo","tags":"donotpay,civilprocedure,law,complaint,joshuabrowder,jonathanfaridian,edelson,kathryntewson,plaintiff,cbsnews,government,causeofaction,amazon,jayedelson,magnitskyact,englishpeople,law2ccrime,jon,lawsuit,corruptioninrussia","channel":"tech","section":"news"}"></div><div class="bt-wrapper"><span data-uid="5d260804c9-384" class="bt-uid-tg" style="display:none !important;text-align:center" data-css-selector="ad-container.ad-mobile"></span></div></div><div class="sc-17kx9cd-1 sc-17kx9cd-3 bGgkuB kTRrxu"></div></div><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv">And it does seem a little odd that someone with a formal legal education would be using an online service to draft demand letters. Gizmodo reached out to Faridians legal team for more information, yet did not immediately receive a response. However, <span><a class="sc-1out364-0 dPMosf sc-145m8ut-0 jCErAQ js_link" data-ga="[["Embedded Url","External link","https://www.cbsnews.com/sanfrancisco/news/class-action-suit-seeks-redress-from-robot-lawyer-practicing-law-without-license/",{"metric25":1}]]" href="https://www.cbsnews.com/sanfrancisco/news/class-action-suit-seeks-redress-from-robot-lawyer-practicing-law-without-license/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">to CBS News</a></span>, attorney Edelson said, Jon is not a lawyer and has never held himself out as such. As his LinkedIn profile explained, he took classes in pursuit of a JD at American Heritage. We agree that the profile could have been clearer and Jon has updated it. </p><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv">In addition to the tweet thread, Browder also shared the following statement with Gizmodo via text message:</p><blockquote data-type="BlockQuote" class="sc-8hxd3p-0 eXwMsK"><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv">DoNotPay respectfully denies the false allegations. The named plaintiff has submitted dozens of successful cases to DoNotPay and the cases highlighted in this lawsuit are meritless. Furthermore, the case is being filed by a lawyer who has personally been paid hundreds of millions from class actions, so its unsurprising that he would accuse an AI of unauthorized practice of law. We will defend ourselves vigorously.</p></blockquote><div class="sc-17kx9cd-5 kDVAgq js_ad-mobile-dynamic js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic"><div class="sc-17kx9cd-1 sc-17kx9cd-2 bGgkuB cLmdPT"></div><div class="sc-17kx9cd-4 bNalOf ad-unit ad-mobile"><div class="sc-17kx9cd-0 fjNuCW">Advertisement</div><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-MOBILE_IN_POST ad-mobile placement-default" data-dfp-site-code="gm.gizmodo" data-ad-unit="MOBILE_IN_POST" data-targeting="{"pos":"mobile_inpost","postId":"1850218589","blogName":"gizmodo","tags":"donotpay,civilprocedure,law,complaint,joshuabrowder,jonathanfaridian,edelson,kathryntewson,plaintiff,cbsnews,government,causeofaction,amazon,jayedelson,magnitskyact,englishpeople,law2ccrime,jon,lawsuit,corruptioninrussia","channel":"tech","section":"news"}"></div><div class="bt-wrapper"><span data-uid="5d260804c9-384" class="bt-uid-tg" style="display:none !important;text-align:center" data-css-selector="ad-container.ad-mobile"></span></div></div><div class="sc-17kx9cd-1 sc-17kx9cd-3 bGgkuB kTRrxu"></div></div><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv">Which brings us to the question of who is we and how, exactly, will DoNotPay opt to defend itself? Will the company lean on the established mores of the legal institution and hire a law firm, or will it be self-representing with a robot? </p><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv">Out of curiosity, I ran the companys statement through a few different AI-generated content detectors, to get a sense of Browders strategy thus far. <span><a class="sc-1out364-0 dPMosf sc-145m8ut-0 jCErAQ js_link" data-ga="[["Embedded Url","External link","https://copyleaks.com/ai-content-detector",{"metric25":1}]]" href="https://copyleaks.com/ai-content-detector" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Most of</a></span> <span><a class="sc-1out364-0 dPMosf sc-145m8ut-0 jCErAQ js_link" data-ga="[["Embedded Url","External link","https://hivemoderation.com/ai-generated-content-detection",{"metric25":1}]]" href="https://hivemoderation.com/ai-generated-content-detection" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">them suggested</a></span> the text was highly likely to have been written by a human (although in most cases I had to paste the statement more than once to meet the minimum word count). OpenAIs <span><a class="sc-1out364-0 dPMosf sc-145m8ut-0 jCErAQ js_link" data-ga="[["Embedded Url","External link","https://platform.openai.com/ai-text-classifier",{"metric25":1}]]" href="https://platform.openai.com/ai-text-classifier" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">own text classifier</a></span> listed the statement (repeated 3x to meet the min) as possibly AI-generated. <span><a class="sc-1out364-0 dPMosf sc-145m8ut-0 jCErAQ js_link" data-ga="[["Embedded Url","Internal link","https://gizmodo.com/open-ai-chatgpt-ai-text-detector-1850055005",{"metric25":1}]]" href="https://gizmodo.com/open-ai-chatgpt-ai-text-detector-1850055005">Though, no AI-detector is perfectly reliable</a></span>. </p><div class="sc-17kx9cd-5 kDVAgq js_ad-mobile-dynamic js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic"><div class="sc-17kx9cd-1 sc-17kx9cd-2 bGgkuB cLmdPT"></div><div class="sc-17kx9cd-4 bNalOf ad-unit ad-mobile"><div class="sc-17kx9cd-0 fjNuCW">Advertisement</div><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-MOBILE_IN_POST ad-mobile placement-default" data-dfp-site-code="gm.gizmodo" data-ad-unit="MOBILE_IN_POST" data-targeting="{"pos":"mobile_inpost","postId":"1850218589","blogName":"gizmodo","tags":"donotpay,civilprocedure,law,complaint,joshuabrowder,jonathanfaridian,edelson,kathryntewson,plaintiff,cbsnews,government,causeofaction,amazon,jayedelson,magnitskyact,englishpeople,law2ccrime,jon,lawsuit,corruptioninrussia","channel":"tech","section":"news"}"></div><div class="bt-wrapper"><span data-uid="5d260804c9-384" class="bt-uid-tg" style="display:none !important;text-align:center" data-css-selector="ad-container.ad-mobile"></span></div></div><div class="sc-17kx9cd-1 sc-17kx9cd-3 bGgkuB kTRrxu"></div></div><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv">Gizmodo also asked Browder directly if DoNotPay would be hiring a lawyer for its defense, or self-defending in court using the companys own tools. In response, Browder declined to respond and said, I apologize given the pending nature of the litigation I cant comment further. However, in his Thursday tweet thread, <span><a class="sc-1out364-0 dPMosf sc-145m8ut-0 jCErAQ js_link" data-ga="[["Embedded Url","External link","https://twitter.com/jbrowder1/status/1633880549495275529",{"metric25":1}]]" href="https://twitter.com/jbrowder1/status/1633880549495275529" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">the CEO wrote</a></span>, We may even use our robot lawyer in the case.</p><div class="js_ymal-below-post"></div><div class="sc-1or3yyu-5 hNjGzN js_more-below-post"></div><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv"><strong>Update 3/13/2023, 12:48 P.M. readabilityObject.title: DoNotPay, the 'Robot Lawyer,' Is Being Sued
readabilityObject.content:
The startup behind the worlds first robot lawyer, DoNotPay, is gearing up for one of its first big court battles. And this time it probably cant just back out of the case, as DoNotPay is the defendant. The company is facing a class action lawsuit over allegations that it misled customers and misrepresented its product.

The FTC Just Prescribed a Can of Whoop Ass on Health Data

  • Off
  • English

In the complaint (embedded below) filed March 3 in a San Francisco court and published Thursday, the plaintiffs legal team claims that DoNotPays description of itself as the worlds first robot lawyer is incorrect and unlawful. Further it alleges that the companys self-billing and lofty promises led its customers to believe they were receiving high quality legal advice and documents when they werent.

Unfortunately for its customers, DoNotPay is not actually a robot, a lawyer, nor a law firm. DoNotPay does not have a law degree, is not barred in any jurisdiction, and is not supervised by any lawyer, the suit reads. DoNotPay is merely a website with a repository ofunfortunately, substandardlegal documents that at best fills in a legal adlib based on information input by customers, it adds. The legal filing goes on to accuse the company of violating California code by practicing law without a license.

Among other things, the suit cites a DoNotPay customer review in which someone reportedly tried to use the service to dispute two parking tickets and ended up paying more money because the company didnt respond to a summons. After trying to cancel their account, the customer was still charged a subscription fee by DoNotPay, per the lawsuit.

Though Gizmodo couldnt immediately locate this particular review, the internet is chock-full of poor reviews of the startup that repeatedly reference challenges canceling subscriptionswhich is deeply ironic considering one of the primary use cases the company has claimed for itself is in helping consumers navigate corporate bureaucracy to cancel subscriptions and get their money back.

The lawsuit further goes into the specific case of primary plaintiff, Jonathan Faridian. It claims that Faridian used DoNotPays services up until January 2023 and found them severely lacking. The complaint alleges that, in at least one instance, DoNotPay failed to deliver demand letters to their intended recipients. It also states that, on several occasions, documents Faridian purchased from DoNotPay were so poorly or inaccurately drafted that he could not even use them.

DoNotPay is a company thats made a name for itself on the internet for its claims of helping customers to get out of parking tickets, reclaim funds from cable companies, and manage other low-grade legal and consumer snafusmostly by generating template based documents.

Yet earlier this year, the company announced it was aiming higher than it had before with the help of OpenAIs ChatGPT. DoNotPay claimed it was taking a pilot version of an AI-powered robot lawyer into the court room, to fight a speeding ticket charge before a judge. The companys founder and CEO, Joshua Browder, also offered to pay $1 million to any lawyer willing to let its artificial intelligence argue a case before the U.S. Supreme Court. Neither the traffic court, nor the Supreme Court dreams panned out for DoNotPay, though. A bevvy of legal threats shut down Browders lofty goal of disrupting the legal industry.

Since then, the company and Browder have faced a wave of criticism, most prominently from those involved in the legal field, like paralegal Kathryn Tewsons viral takedown. Tewson has also begun legal proceedings against Browder and DoNotPay, alleging fraud in a lawsuit filed to New York States Supreme Court in February.

Back in January

 

Browder subsequently announced DoNotPay would step back from its courtroom and lawyer-replacement goals (calling them distractions), and pivot its focus fully to consumer rights. Yet the company continues to bill itself the worlds first robot lawyer, on its website.

In response to the class action suit CEO Browder, posted a lengthy Twitter thread criticizing the basis of the complaint and the law firm arguing the case against him. His thread mostly focuses in on Jay Edelson, the senior attorney on the case who is well-known for aggressively going after major tech companies like Google, Apple, and Amazonand winning large settlements.

Jay Edelson inspired me to start DoNotPay because he symbolizes everything wrong with the law, Browder tweetedciting a 2015 class action Facebook settlement in which Edelsons firm earned $97.5 million while most people eligible for compensation who filled out the claim form got a few hundred bucks.

Granted, that payout to the law firm is a pretty standard 15% fee on a hefty $650 million settlement fund, per the U.S. Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals that rejected Facebooks objections to the attorney fees in 2022.

Browders tweets also critique Faridian as a plaintiff. According to Faridians LinkedIn profile, he is an entrepreneur who studied law at the American Heritage University School of Law. He also claims to be currently studying law at Purdue Universitys online Concord Law School.

And it does seem a little odd that someone with a formal legal education would be using an online service to draft demand letters. Gizmodo reached out to Faridians legal team for more information, yet did not immediately receive a response. However, to CBS News, attorney Edelson said, Jon is not a lawyer and has never held himself out as such. As his LinkedIn profile explained, he took classes in pursuit of a JD at American Heritage. We agree that the profile could have been clearer and Jon has updated it.

In addition to the tweet thread, Browder also shared the following statement with Gizmodo via text message:

DoNotPay respectfully denies the false allegations. The named plaintiff has submitted dozens of successful cases to DoNotPay and the cases highlighted in this lawsuit are meritless. Furthermore, the case is being filed by a lawyer who has personally been paid hundreds of millions from class actions, so its unsurprising that he would accuse an AI of unauthorized practice of law. We will defend ourselves vigorously.

Which brings us to the question of who is we and how, exactly, will DoNotPay opt to defend itself? Will the company lean on the established mores of the legal institution and hire a law firm, or will it be self-representing with a robot?

Out of curiosity, I ran the companys statement through a few different AI-generated content detectors, to get a sense of Browders strategy thus far. Most of them suggested the text was highly likely to have been written by a human (although in most cases I had to paste the statement more than once to meet the minimum word count). OpenAIs own text classifier listed the statement (repeated 3x to meet the min) as possibly AI-generated. Though, no AI-detector is perfectly reliable.

Gizmodo also asked Browder directly if DoNotPay would be hiring a lawyer for its defense, or self-defending in court using the companys own tools. In response, Browder declined to respond and said, I apologize given the pending nature of the litigation I cant comment further. However, in his Thursday tweet thread, the CEO wrote, We may even use our robot lawyer in the case.

Update 3/13/2023, 12:48 P.M. ET: This post has been updated with additional information about another, earlier lawsuit filed against DoNotPay.

Among other things, the suit cites a DoNotPay customer review in which someone reportedly tried to use the service to dispute two parking tickets and ended up paying more money because the company didnt respond to a summons. After trying to cancel their account, the customer was still charged a subscription fee by DoNotPay, per the lawsuit. Though Gizmodo couldnt immediately locate this particular review, the internet is chock-full of poor reviews of the startup that repeatedly reference challenges canceling subscriptionswhich is deeply ironic considering one of the primary use cases the company has claimed for itself is in helping consumers navigate corporate bureaucracy to cancel subscriptions and get their money back. The lawsuit further goes into the specific case of primary plaintiff, Jonathan Faridian. It claims that Faridian used DoNotPays services up until January 2023 and found them severely lacking. The complaint alleges that, in at least one instance, DoNotPay failed to deliver demand letters to their intended recipients. It also states that, on several occasions, documents Faridian purchased from DoNotPay were so poorly or inaccurately drafted that he could not even use them.DoNotPay is a company thats made a name for itself on the internet for its claims of helping customers to get out of parking tickets, reclaim funds from cable companies, and manage other low-grade legal and consumer snafusmostly by generating template based documents. We will defend ourselves vigorously.Which brings us to the question of who is we and how, exactly, will DoNotPay opt to defend itself? Will the company lean on the established mores of the legal institution and hire a law firm, or will it be self-representing with a robot? Out of curiosity, I ran the companys statement through a few different AI-generated content detectors, to get a sense of Browders strategy thus far. Most of them suggested the text was highly likely to have been written by a human (although in most cases I had to paste the statement more than once to meet the minimum word count). OpenAIs own text classifier listed the statement (repeated 3x to meet the min) as possibly AI-generated. Though, no AI-detector is perfectly reliable. Gizmodo also asked Browder directly if DoNotPay would be hiring a lawyer for its defense, or self-defending in court using the companys own tools. In response, Browder declined to respond and said, I apologize given the pending nature of the litigation I cant comment further. However, in his Thursday tweet thread, the CEO wrote, We may even use our robot lawyer in the case.Update 3/13/2023, 12:48 P.M. jsonLd.headline: DoNotPay, the 'Robot Lawyer,' Is Being Sued
jsonLd.description: A class action lawsuit claims Joshua Browder's start-up misled consumers by peddling "substandard legal documents" and providing "unauthorized legal services."
jsonLd.articleBody:
The startup behind the worlds first robot lawyer, DoNotPay, is gearing up for one of its first big court battles. And this time it probably cant just back out of the case, as DoNotPay is the defendant. The company is facing a class action lawsuit over allegations that it misled customers and misrepresented its product. 


In the complaint (embedded below) filed March 3 in a San Francisco court and published Thursday, the plaintiffs legal team claims that DoNotPays description of itself as the worlds first robot lawyer is incorrect and unlawful. Further it alleges that the companys self-billing and lofty promises led its customers to believe they were receiving high quality legal advice and documents when they werent. 

Unfortunately for its customers, DoNotPay is not actually a robot, a lawyer, nor a law firm. DoNotPay does not have a law degree, is not barred in any jurisdiction, and is not supervised by any lawyer, the suit reads. DoNotPay is merely a website with a repository ofunfortunately, substandardlegal documents that at best fills in a legal adlib based on information input by customers, it adds. The legal filing goes on to accuse the company of violating California code by practicing law without a license.

 Among other things, the suit cites a DoNotPay customer review in which someone reportedly tried to use the service to dispute two parking tickets and ended up paying more money because the company didnt respond to a summons. After trying to cancel their account, the customer was still charged a subscription fee by DoNotPay, per the lawsuit. 

Though Gizmodo couldnt immediately locate this particular review, the internet is chock-full of poor reviews of the startup that repeatedly reference challenges canceling subscriptionswhich is deeply ironic considering one of the primary use cases the company has claimed for itself is in helping consumers navigate corporate bureaucracy to cancel subscriptions and get their money back. 

The lawsuit further goes into the specific case of primary plaintiff, Jonathan Faridian. It claims that Faridian used DoNotPays services up until January 2023 and found them severely lacking. The complaint alleges that, in at least one instance, DoNotPay failed to deliver demand letters to their intended recipients. It also states that, on several occasions, documents Faridian purchased from DoNotPay were so poorly or inaccurately drafted that he could not even use them.

DoNotPay is a company thats made a name for itself on the internet for its claims of helping customers to get out of parking tickets, reclaim funds from cable companies, and manage other low-grade legal and consumer snafusmostly by generating template based documents. 

Yet earlier this year, the company announced it was aiming higher than it had before with the help of OpenAIs ChatGPT. DoNotPay claimed it was taking a pilot version of an AI-powered robot lawyer into the court room, to fight a speeding ticket charge before a judge. The companys founder and CEO, Joshua Browder, also offered to pay $1 million to any lawyer willing to let its artificial intelligence argue a case before the U.S. Supreme Court. Neither the traffic court, nor the Supreme Court dreams panned out for DoNotPay, though. A bevvy of legal threats shut down Browders lofty goal of disrupting the legal industry. 

Since then, the company and Browder have faced a wave of criticism, most prominently from those involved in the legal field, like paralegal Kathryn Tewsons viral takedown. Tewson has also begun legal proceedings against Browder and DoNotPay, alleging fraud in a lawsuit filed to New York States Supreme Court in February.

Back in JanuaryBrowder subsequently announced DoNotPay would step back from its courtroom and lawyer-replacement goals (calling them distractions), and pivot its focus fully to consumer rights. Yet the company continues to bill itself the worlds first robot lawyer, on its website. 

In response to the class action suit CEO Browder, posted a lengthy Twitter thread criticizing the basis of the complaint and the law firm arguing the case against him. His thread mostly focuses in on Jay Edelson, the senior attorney on the case who is well-known for aggressively going after major tech companies like Google, Apple, and Amazonand winning large settlements. 

Jay Edelson inspired me to start DoNotPay because he symbolizes everything wrong with the law, Browder tweetedciting a 2015 class action Facebook settlement in which Edelsons firm earned $97.5 million while most people eligible for compensation who filled out the claim form got a few hundred bucks. 

Granted, that payout to the law firm is a pretty standard 15% fee on a hefty $650 million settlement fund, per the U.S. Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals that rejected Facebooks objections to the attorney fees in 2022.

Browders tweets also critique Faridian as a plaintiff. According to Faridians LinkedIn profile, he is an entrepreneur who studied law at the American Heritage University School of Law. He also claims to be currently studying law at Purdue Universitys online Concord Law School.

And it does seem a little odd that someone with a formal legal education would be using an online service to draft demand letters. Gizmodo reached out to Faridians legal team for more information, yet did not immediately receive a response. However, to CBS News, attorney Edelson said, Jon is not a lawyer and has never held himself out as such. As his LinkedIn profile explained, he took classes in pursuit of a JD at American Heritage. We agree that the profile could have been clearer and Jon has updated it. 

In addition to the tweet thread, Browder also shared the following statement with Gizmodo via text message:

DoNotPay respectfully denies the false allegations. The named plaintiff has submitted dozens of successful cases to DoNotPay and the cases highlighted in this lawsuit are meritless. Furthermore, the case is being filed by a lawyer who has personally been paid hundreds of millions from class actions, so its unsurprising that he would accuse an AI of unauthorized practice of law. We will defend ourselves vigorously.

Which brings us to the question of who is we and how, exactly, will DoNotPay opt to defend itself? Will the company lean on the established mores of the legal institution and hire a law firm, or will it be self-representing with a robot? 

Out of curiosity, I ran the companys statement through a few different AI-generated content detectors, to get a sense of Browders strategy thus far. Most of them suggested the text was highly likely to have been written by a human (although in most cases I had to paste the statement more than once to meet the minimum word count). OpenAIs own text classifier listed the statement (repeated 3x to meet the min) as possibly AI-generated. Though, no AI-detector is perfectly reliable. 

Gizmodo also asked Browder directly if DoNotPay would be hiring a lawyer for its defense, or self-defending in court using the companys own tools. In response, Browder declined to respond and said, I apologize given the pending nature of the litigation I cant comment further. However, in his Thursday tweet thread, the CEO wrote, We may even use our robot lawyer in the case.

Update 3/13/2023, 12:48 P.M. ET: This post has been updated with additional information about another, earlier lawsuit filed against DoNotPay.
